p: The yield and quality of essential oils vary with genetics, agroclimatic conditions, cultivation techniques, soil conditions, harvest time, etc. Therefore, chemical compositions and major compounds of essential oils vary in different habitats, and their bioactivity is closely associated with changes in their composition. Cinnamic aldehyde, for example, showed MIC ranging from 0.5 to 1000 Î¼g/mL against 20 strains of P. aeruginosa [ 33] and therapeutic potential by inhibiting infections related to biofilm production by S. aureus [ 34]. The turmerone compound found in C. longa demonstrated activity against E. coli [ 35] while showed no activity against Gram-positive bacterial strains [ 36].
